awd_titl_txt: WALRUS - Walrus Adaptability and Long-term Responses; Using multi-proxy data to project Sustainability
awd_abstract_narration:
The Pacific walrus (Odobenus rosmarus divergens) is one of many species affected by recent environmental change in the Arctic. Much attention has focused on the loss of sea ice recorded from 2007-2012, the concomitant appearance of thousands of walruses on Alaska's and Russia's beaches, and the unfortunate consequence of large numbers of trampling mortalities.  In addition, an unusual number of walruses in poor body condition were reported on Wrangel Island in 2007, many of which subsequently died.  While walrus haul-out and mortality events are not historically isolated occurrences, these past haul-outs on Alaska's coasts, associated with reduced sea ice abundance, signify a change to this population.  These occurrences are disquieting taken together with a decrease in estimated walrus based on surveys from 2006 versus 1990, (129,000  in 2006 compared to 200,000 in 1990), and current data on reduced fertility.  The Pacific walrus is of critical importance to subsistence consumers in Alaska (and other areas of the Arctic).  Despite impressive data from in-depth studies of Pacific walruses over the last 40-50 years, it is difficult to implement proposed co-management and conservation plans based on data from such a relatively short time span, much less project the impact of additional changes to the Arctic ecosystem on both walruses and humans subsisting on them.

This project aims to integrate several disciplines including archaeology, ethnology, biology, and ecology using diverse sources of data including DNA, stable isotope, steroid, and trace element analysis as well as to ascertain long-term trends of walrus feeding ecology, foraging location, and stock genetics over the last two millenia. This time frame includes large climatic anomalies such as the Medieval Warm and the Little Ice Age, thereby presenting scientists with the possibility of understanding how walruses adapt during times of stress and change.  Present-day samples will be obtained from Alaskan subsistence hunters, historic samples will be acquired from museums, and prehistoric samples from archaeological collections.  Each type of data will act as a building block to better understand walruses and how they adapt to change in Arctic ecosystems.  DNA analysis will provide insights into population bottlenecks and potentially adaptive differentiation between stocks.  Stable isotope analysis of bone collagen and growth ring layers of teeth will define overall feeding ecologies of individuals through time.  Trace element analysis will reveal foraging locations, potential population structure, and changes of essential and non-essential elements over time.  Bone steroid hormones (i.e., stress hormones) can delineate population structure and health over time, and translation of historic taped interviews and use of previously archived studies will reveal traditional knowledge of walrus habitats and feeding habits over the last 100 years.

REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
This project was undertaken to better understand changes in walruses’ diets, reproductive and stress levels, and population structure throughout time periods of large climatic change in the last 3500 years. Our WALRUS team developed new ways to determine the ages at which walruses were weaned and at which they first reproduced, as well as how to determine concentrations of stress and sex hormones, over thousands of years in bones and teeth. In addition, we used more established methods to trace diet and population structure over these same long time frames. We also found a way of tracing of contaminant and petroleum sources through walrus teeth in more recent individuals. These tools can also be used in research of other marine mammal populations as well as aid in management and decision making. We found that although changes in steroid hormones, diets, and behavioral patterns exist, Pacific walruses have been extremely resilient to climate change and anthropogenic pressures over the last few thousand years. However, this may not be the case for the extreme changes we are seeing currently.

 

For example, our research showed that today’s walruses are no more stressed than those in the past, though there is a weak correlation between September sea ice extent and the stress biomarker cortisol and we have shown that higher female reproductive activity is associated with greater Chukchi Sea ice cover in September. We have also shown that variability in walruses’ diet was greater in low-ice intervals, which could be due to a decreased availability of preferred food sources. However, sea ice extent was not the primary driver of dietary change over time and modern walruses’ diets are not consistent with the diets of walruses in other low ice intervals of the past. In fact, walruses’ position in the food chain is lower now, and their feeding the least diverse, than the last few thousand years, so either the Bering and Chukchi seas ecosystems are still in transition or we have a state not yet seen for the last 4000 years.

 

The WALRUS project graduated an MS student, a PhD student, and trained numerous undergraduate and graduate students in bio/isogeochemical techniques, museum studies, data archiving, field work, and sample collecting. A second PhD student has incorporated a chapter based on the ancient DNA data derived from this project and will graduate in May 2023. Nine papers have been published in peer-reviewed manuscripts with graduate and undergraduate students as first authors. One more manuscript has been completed and will be submitted before the end of the calendar year. In four cases the research was ground breaking, showcasing either new bio/iso geochemical techniques or applying them in innovative ways.  In total, 800 samples were collected from museum and archaeological collections and were processed for hormones, stable isotopes, trace element analyses, and ancient DNA. In total, 43 posters and presentations were given at conferences at the local to international level (22 by graduate students and 5 by undergraduate students).

 

Beyond the scientific outputs, 55 tapes that were stored at the Rasmuson Library, University of Alaska Fairbanks for up to 30 years and that contain traditional ecological knowledge were transcribed and digitized for easier access. Copies of transcripts and interviews were made available for distribution among family members of interviewees and for the local schools and tribes. Native subsistence hunters were integral to the project, collecting samples for three years. Six community visits were made prior to the pandemic by project PIs and students for meetings with hunters, tribal leaders, and the Eskimo Walrus Commission. The project sponsored three Rural Alaska Honors Institute high school students who participated in scientific research in the Misarti and Horstmann labs. The students, all from coastal Alaskan communities, generated posters describing their research and two were presented by the students at a national conference. A workshop was convened with Russian and Alaskan coastal community members, management entities and researchers to determine the research priorities of communities as they pertain to walruses. A workshop report was generated and distributed to resource managers, funders and communities. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/12/2022
Modified by: Nicole Misarti
